Award.AbstractNarration: The Combined Array for Research in Millimeter Astronomy (CARMA) was formed from the merger of three telescope arrays supported by the Division of Astronomical Science's University Radio Observatories (URO) Program: Caltech's Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) array of six 10.4-meter-diameter telescopes, the Berkeley Illinois Maryland Association (BIMA) array of nine 6.1-meter-diameter telescopes, and the University of Chicago's Sunyaev-Zeldovitch Array of eight 3.5-meter-diameter telescopes. CARMA currently achieves resolutions as high as 0.2 arcseconds at a wavelength of 1mm and, due to its heterogeneous combination of telescope diameters, provides excellent imaging over a wide range of angular scales. Science enabled by CARMA covers a broad range of astronomical topics, including star formation and molecular clouds, studies of external galaxies, and the investigation of solar system objects. CARMA is a pathfinder for the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) and a pipeline for training experts in the field of millimeter interferometry to take full advantage of ALMA's capabilities for US astronomy. Users outside the CARMA collaboration receive 30% of all observing time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant enabled the University of Maryland to participate in the operation of the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter-wave Astronomy (CARMA) and to perform scientific research with the array. We used the array to study how stars and galaxies form and evolved. In the case of nearby forming stars, we studied the disks around young stars which are the places that planets form. These studies help us to understand how our galaxy and our Solar System formed and how unique our Solar System is among the stars in our Galaxy.

As part of our operational and scientific activities, we participated in training a new generation of scientists and inspired a new generation of students. The training included learning the skills and knowledge-base to operate a complex scientific instrument, to write complex software for the analysis of data, to organize and run projects, to work in team environments, and to write logical scientific articles. The students with Ph.D.s from our group have gone on to a range of technical careers including the academic pursuit of astronomy research and teaching, analysis of imaging data in the commercial and defense arena, scientific administration positions in scientific agencies and organizations, and positions in commercial companies in the space-related industry. The common theme is that  the technical skills and knowledge-base acquired in their graduate years enabled success in their technically-oriented career paths.

Though the desimination of research results and the engagement of students and the public in the excitement of astronomy research, we participated in inpsiring the interest of  the new generation of students in STEM careers.
